Synopsis: Requiring a certain assistant State's Attorney with knowledge of the case to meet with a victim of sexually assaultive behavior or the victim's representative within 20 days after receiving a request from the victim regarding a decision by the Office of the State's Attorney  not to file a charging document or to dismiss charges against an alleged suspect; requiring the assistant State's Attorney, at the meeting, to explain the justification for a certain decision; and establishing certain requirements for the meeting.
bill_summary: The bill requires an assistant State’s Attorney to meet with victims of sexually assaultive behavior within 20 days if the charges are dismissed or not filed, to explain the reasons for these decisions.
responsible_party: Office of the State’s Attorney in Maryland
stakeholders: Victims of sexually assaultive behavior in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Baltimore County Board of Education - Student Member - Voting and Training
Synopsis: Authorizing the student member of the Baltimore County Board of Education to vote on capital and operating budget matters; requiring certain members of the county board and the executive leadership of the Baltimore County public school system to develop a certain draft curriculum for budget training for student members of the county board and submit the draft curriculum to the county board for review; and requiring each student member of the board to complete the budget training within 2 months of the student's election to the board.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the student member of the Baltimore County Board of Education to vote on budget matters, requires the development of a budget training curriculum, and mandates that student members complete this training within two months of election to be eligible to vote on budget issues.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of Education and Baltimore County Public School System's Division of Business Services
stakeholders: Students in Baltimore County public schools, particularly those serving as student members of the Board of Education
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: State Designations – State Spirit – Maryland Rye
Synopsis: Designating Maryland Rye or Maryland Rye Whiskey as the State spirit.
bill_summary: The bill designates Maryland Rye or Maryland Rye Whiskey as the official State spirit of Maryland, recognizing its historical significance and local agricultural connection.
responsible_party: Maryland General Assembly and the Maryland Department of Commerce (or relevant state agency overseeing state symbols and local spirits)
stakeholders: Local distilleries, farmers growing rye, residents of Maryland, and the broader spirits industry in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill may support local distilleries and farmers by promoting Maryland Rye Whiskey, potentially aiding small business growth and sustainability.

Title: Maryland Estate Tax - Portability - Time Period for Election
Synopsis: Altering the period of time within which a person is required to file a Maryland estate tax return for the purpose of allowing a surviving spouse to take into account the deceased spousal unused exclusion amount to be consistent with the time for making a federal election; and applying the Act retroactively to any decedents dying on or after January 1, 2019.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland estate tax law to change the deadline for filing estate tax returns to align with federal election periods for surviving spouses to utilize unused spousal estate tax exclusions, retroactively applying to deaths on or after January 1, 2019.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office
stakeholders: Surviving spouses, estate executors, and beneficiaries involved in estate planning and administration in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts estate tax filings and does not directly influence small business failure rates.

Title: Income Tax - Subtraction Modification for Adoption Expenses - Alterations
Synopsis: Altering eligibility for and the amount of a subtraction modification under the Maryland income tax for a taxpayer who adopts a child during the taxable year.
bill_summary: The bill increases the maximum amount of Maryland income tax subtraction modification for adoption expenses, especially for adoptions involving children with special needs, and clarifies eligibility criteria based on the child's residency status at the time of adoption.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Revenue
stakeholders: Individuals adopting children in Maryland, especially those adopting children with special needs or from out-of-state
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Real Property - Unlawfully Restrictive Covenants - Modification by Counties or Municipalities
Synopsis: Authorizing a county or municipality to execute and record a restrictive covenant modification to an unlawfully restrictive covenant for a property within the boundaries of the county or municipality after providing persons with an ownership interest in the property with 30 days' written notice; and providing that persons with an ownership interest in property that is subject to an unlawfully restrictive covenant may decline action by a county or municipality to execute and record a restrictive covenant modification.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Maryland counties and municipalities to modify unlawfully restrictive covenants related to race, religion, or national origin on properties within their boundaries, provided certain notice and consent procedures are followed.
responsible_party: County or municipal government agencies responsible for property records and enforcement.
stakeholders: Property owners within Maryland counties and municipalities, especially those affected by unlawful restrictive covenants.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily addresses property covenants and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: State Personnel - Education and Transportation - Grievance Procedures
Synopsis: Authorizing a certain employee or certain exclusive representative to initiate a grievance procedure under certain provisions of law; requiring certain decision makers in a grievance procedure in certain higher education systems to award certain damages under certain circumstances; requiring certain employee grievance procedures to include certain redress for certain violations; requiring the Secretary of Transportation to be consistent with certain provisions of law and include redress for certain violations; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates and clarifies grievance procedures for State personnel, education, and transportation employees in Maryland, including provisions for employee redress, damages, and disciplinary actions.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Transportation, Maryland Higher Education Commission, and the relevant State personnel agencies and offices.
stakeholders: State employees in education, transportation, and other state agencies, including faculty, staff, and contractual employees.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it establishes procedures for employee grievances and disciplinary actions within state agencies.

Title: Nonpublic Schools and Child Care Providers - Corporal Punishment - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting the State Board of Education from issuing a certificate of approval to noncollegiate educational institutions that do not have a policy prohibiting the administration of corporal punishment; requiring regulations adopted by the State Board for the registration of family child care homes and large family child care homes and the licensing and operation of child care centers to prohibit corporal punishment; and requiring the State Board to identify certain methods in a certain overall plan.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits the use of corporal punishment in nonpublic schools and child care providers, requiring the State Board of Education to identify methods to eliminate such practices and ensuring that nonpublic educational institutions and child care providers have policies against corporal punishment.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Board of Education
stakeholders: Students in nonpublic schools and children in child care centers and family child care homes in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill may reduce small business failure by promoting safer, more compliant child care and educational environments, potentially increasing trust and enrollment.

Title: Victim Services Programs – Supplementing Federal Funding and Support (Victim Services Stabilization Act)
Synopsis: Providing for the stable funding and support of trauma-informed, high-quality programs and services for victims of crime; requiring the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services to help support certain programs providing services for victims of crime; requiring the Office to consult with certain individuals and organizations regarding the allocation of certain funding; and requiring the Governor to include certain funding in the State budget.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a program to support and fund victim services across Maryland by supplementing federal funding, ensuring stable and continuous services for crime victims, and coordinating funding and support among various organizations.
responsible_party: The Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
stakeholders: Victims of crime and organizations providing victim support services in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; its focus is on victim support services.

Title: Natural Resources - Wildlife Advisory Commission - Membership
Synopsis: Increasing the membership of the Wildlife Advisory Commission; requiring the Governor to appoint a member to the Wildlife Advisory Commission who is an academic researcher with expertise in wildlife biology, wildlife conservation, wildlife management, or ecology; and requiring the membership of the Commission to include representation from the farming, hunting, wildlife preservation, and passive wildlife recreation communities.
bill_summary: This bill increases the membership of the Maryland Wildlife Advisory Commission from 9 to 10 members, including the appointment of an academic researcher with expertise in wildlife biology, conservation, management, or ecology, and emphasizes diverse stakeholder representation.
responsible_party: Governor of Maryland, who appoints members to the Wildlife Advisory Commission.
stakeholders: Wildlife conservation communities, hunting and fishing communities, farmers, passive wildlife recreation enthusiasts, and academic researchers in wildlife fields in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on wildlife conservation and advisory commission membership, with no direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Automatic Expungement - Clarification
Synopsis: Clarifying the language of provisions of law requiring the expungement of certain records maintained by the State or a political subdivision of the State relating to the charging of certain offenses under certain circumstances and notification of a certain right to expungement.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies the laws regarding automatic expungement of certain criminal and civil records in Maryland, specifying the conditions and timelines for expungement and notification procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland State courts and law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Individuals with records related to certain criminal or civil offenses, law enforcement agencies, and the criminal justice system in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts criminal record management and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Currency - Campaign Finance Prohibitions - Disclosures by Financial Institutions
Synopsis: Prohibiting certain persons subject to campaign finance regulation from making or accepting monetary contributions or monetary donations using any currency other than United States currency; prohibiting a campaign finance entity or a person acting on behalf of a campaign finance entity from making a monetary expenditure using any currency other than United States currency; authorizing the State Administrator of Elections or the Administrator's designee to investigate certain potential violations of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits campaign finance entities and individuals from making or accepting monetary contributions, donations, or expenditures using cryptocurrencies other than United States currency. It also authorizes investigations and penalties for violations, and updates definitions related to financial institutions to include virtual currency transmitters.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Board of Elections and the State Administrator of Elections.
stakeholders: Campaign finance entities, political candidates, donors, and individuals involved in campaign contributions and expenditures in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily targets campaign finance regulations and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Probation Before Judgment - Probation Agreements
Synopsis: Authorizing a court to stay the entering of a conviction, defer further proceedings, and place a certain defendant on probation subject to reasonable conditions if the court finds facts justifying a finding of guilt; authorizing the State and a certain defendant to enter into a probation agreement under certain circumstances; providing that the entry of a probation agreement under the Act shall be considered a probation before judgment for all other purposes under State law; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes courts in Maryland to stay the entry of judgment and place defendants on probation before judgment under certain conditions, including entering into probation agreements that do not admit guilt but allow for deferred sentencing and potential discharge without a conviction.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health and the Administrative Office of the Courts.
stakeholders: Individuals charged with crimes in Maryland, particularly those eligible for probation before judgment, and the criminal justice system.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on criminal probation procedures.

Title: Budget Bill (Fiscal Year 2024)
Synopsis: Making the proposed appropriations contained in the State Budget for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2024, in accordance with Article III, Section 52 of the Maryland Constitution; etc.
bill_summary: The bill is a comprehensive fiscal appropriations act for the State of Maryland for fiscal year 2024, detailing allocations for various departments, agencies, and programs, including supplemental budgets, transfers, and specific project funding.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Budget and Management is responsible for implementing the programs and managing the appropriations.
stakeholders: The stakeholders impacted include Maryland state agencies, local governments, educational institutions, healthcare providers, and residents who benefit from the funded programs and projects.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes several allocations for grants, loans, and support programs that could help small businesses, but the direct impact on small business failure rates is not explicitly detailed.

Title: Creation of a State Debt – Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loan of 2023, and the Maryland Consolidated Capital Bond Loans of 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, and 2022
Synopsis: Authorizing the creation of a State Debt in the amount of $1,218,639,000, the proceeds to be used for certain necessary building, construction, demolition, planning, renovation, conversion, replacement, and capital equipment purchases of the State, for acquiring certain real estate in connection therewith, and for grants to certain subdivisions and other organizations for certain development and improvement purposes; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the issuance of bonds and the creation of a State Debt to fund various capital projects across Maryland, including infrastructure, educational, health, and community development projects, with specific allocations and requirements for matching funds and project oversight.
responsible_party: The Board of Public Works, Maryland Department of Planning, Maryland Historical Trust, Maryland Higher Education Commission, Maryland Department of Education, Maryland Stadium Authority, Maryland Environmental Service, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Maryland Department of Health, Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Maryland Higher Education Commission, and other state agencies.
stakeholders: Residents of Maryland, local governments, educational institutions, health care facilities, community organizations, and various populations benefiting from community development and infrastructure projects.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes funding for community centers, business development, and infrastructure projects that could support small businesses and community organizations, potentially reducing failure rates.

Title: Budget Reconciliation and Financing Act of 2023
Synopsis: Authorizing or altering the distribution of certain revenue; repealing a certain required appropriation to the Revenue Stabilization Account; altering the areas in which certain faculty must specialize to be assigned to provide clinical care at the University of Maryland Capital Region Medical Center; reducing the budgeted Medicaid Deficit Assessment for fiscal year 2024; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes funding and program adjustments related to healthcare, education, and state finances, including providing clinical care at a medical center, funding for investment and pension funds, property tax refunds, and transferring land for conservation.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Department of Assessments and Taxation, Maryland Department of Health, Maryland Energy Administration, and the Department of Natural Resources.
stakeholders: Residents of Maryland, small business owners, homeowners, and public health and education institutions.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes provisions that could indirectly support small businesses through economic development funds and property tax adjustments, but it does not explicitly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Early Childhood Education - Prekindergarten Programs - Montessori Schools and Programs
Synopsis: Altering the eligibility requirements for the Prekindergarten Expansion Grant Program and publicly funded prekindergarten programs to include certain operational requirements, staff credentials, and student-to-staff ratios; requiring Montessori schools and programs to maintain a student-to-classroom personnel ratio of no more than 10 to 1, with a maximum of 20 students if all the students are under the age of 5 years; requiring a classroom teacher to hold a bachelor's degree and be certified by certain organizations; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the requirements for prekindergarten programs in Maryland to include specific operational standards for Montessori schools, such as staff credentials and student-to-staff ratios, to ensure quality early childhood education.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education
stakeholders: Prekindergarten children, Montessori schools, early childhood education providers, families in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By clarifying operational and staffing requirements for Montessori prekindergarten programs, the bill aims to support the stability and quality of these programs, potentially reducing failure rates.

Title: Corporations and Associations - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions governing the issuance of stock, convertible securities, and scrip; clarifying the authority of corporations to hold annual meetings by remote communication; clarifying the application of certain provisions of law to the conversion of a corporation; requiring a real estate investment trust that voluntarily dissolves to file a notice of termination with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland laws governing corporations and associations, including provisions on issuing stock, holding remote meetings, converting corporations, dissolving real estate investment trusts, and regulating statutory trusts, to modernize and clarify legal procedures.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation and the Maryland State Government
stakeholders: Corporations, associations, real estate investment trusts, and their members or stockholders in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions on corporate governance, stock issuance, and trust regulation aim to streamline processes and reduce legal ambiguities, potentially lowering small business failure rates.

Title: Baltimore County - Board of Education - Member Elections and Appointments
Synopsis: Requiring the seven elected members of the Baltimore County Board of Education to be elected in gubernatorial election years; requiring the four appointed members of the Board to be appointed in presidential election years; providing for the termination of the terms of certain appointed members of the Board in 2024; and providing for the  appointment of certain members of the Board in 2028.
bill_summary: The bill changes the election and appointment schedule for the Baltimore County Board of Education, including extending the terms of appointed members and adjusting the years in which new members are appointed or elected.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of Education and the Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Students, parents, and residents of Baltimore County who are affected by the Board of Education's decisions and elections.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure or economic development; it focuses on education governance.

Title: Commission on Public Health - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Commission on Public Health to make recommendations to improve the delivery of foundational public health services in the State; requiring the Commission to conduct an assessment of the foundational public health capabilities of the Maryland Department of Health and local health departments; requiring the Commission to submit to the Governor and certain committees of the General Assembly an interim report by December 1, 2023, and a final report by December 1, 2024, of the Commission's findings and recommendations; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Commission on Public Health to assess and improve the delivery of foundational public health services in Maryland, including areas like disease control, environmental health, maternal health, and health equity, with a focus on addressing major health challenges and disparities.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health and the Commission on Public Health, with academic institutions providing staff support.
stakeholders: Public health residents of Maryland, including vulnerable populations affected by health disparities, and public health professionals and organizations.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on public health system assessment and reform, which may indirectly support small business health initiatives but does not directly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Real Property - Limitations on Summoning Law Enforcement or Emergency Services - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting a landlord from using a lease or form of lease that contains a provision that limits a tenant's ability to summon, or penalizes a tenant or another individual solely for summoning, the assistance of law enforcement or emergency services; prohibiting a landlord from taking certain retaliatory actions because a tenant or another individual summons the assistance of law enforcement or emergency services for certain purposes; prohibiting a local jurisdiction from enacting certain laws; etc.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits landlords from including lease provisions that limit tenants' ability to summon law enforcement or emergency services, and from retaliating against tenants for doing so. It also restricts local governments from enacting laws that penalize or restrict tenants or property owners for summoning emergency services.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development and local government authorities.
stakeholders: Tenants, landlords, property owners, and residents of Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill limits local laws that could impose penalties or restrictions on property owners and tenants related to emergency service summons, potentially reducing legal and financial risks for small property owners.

Title: Howard County - Alcoholic Beverages - Repeal of Petition of Support Requirement Ho. Co. 12-23
Synopsis: Repealing the requirement that an application for an alcoholic beverages license in Howard County include certain petitions of support signed by at least three residents who are owners of real property and registered voters in the district where the business is to be conducted.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the requirement in Howard County for alcoholic beverage license applicants to include petitions of support signed by local residents, simplifying the application process.
responsible_party: Howard County Alcoholic Beverages Board
stakeholders: Applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses in Howard County, including local residents and business owners
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By removing the petition requirement, the bill reduces administrative barriers for small businesses applying for licenses, potentially decreasing failure rates.

Title: St. Mary's County - Golf Carts on Public Highways - Report
Synopsis: Requiring the St. Mary's County Board of County Commissioners to produce a report recommending and describing the areas of St. Mary's County that the County Board considers appropriate for the operation of unregistered golf carts on public highways, subject to certain standards; and requiring the County Board to submit the report to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 1, 2023.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes St. Mary's County to create an exception to registration requirements for golf carts operated on certain public highways, specifically in designated areas that are isolated, have docking facilities, and are part of tourist destinations near Chesapeake Bay. The County must produce a report recommending suitable areas for this exception and submit it to legislative committees by December 1, 2023.
responsible_party: St. Mary's County Board of County Commissioners
stakeholders: Tourists, residents, and visitors in designated areas of St. Mary's County who may operate golf carts on public highways
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but by potentially increasing tourism and local transportation options, it could support small businesses in the designated areas.

Title: Criminal Law - Person in a Position of Authority - Sexual Offenses With a Minor
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "person in a position of authority" applicable to sexual offense in the fourth degree; altering a certain prohibition against a certain person in a position of authority engaging in certain conduct to prohibit a person in a position of authority from engaging in a sexual act, sexual contact, or vaginal intercourse with a minor who is enrolled at a school or participating in a certain program for which the person in authority works; authorizing the imposition of a certain sentence;  etc.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland law to clarify and expand the definition of 'person in a position of authority' and the restrictions on sexual conduct with minors in such positions, including specific prohibitions related to minors enrolled or participating in programs or activities where the person in authority works or has worked.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, Maryland State Department of Education, or other relevant state agencies responsible for oversight of educational and youth programs.
stakeholders: Minors participating in educational, recreational, religious, or governmental programs, and individuals in positions of authority within those programs.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily addresses legal definitions and conduct restrictions; it does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Employment for Minors - Opportunities for Work
Synopsis: Requiring the Commissioner of Labor and Industry to release certain personal information of a minor who has a work permit to employers and apprenticeship sponsors, educational programs and institutions, and local workforce development boards that have requested and have registered with the Maryland Department of Labor for the purpose of receiving the information, if a parent or legal guardian of the minor or the minor elects to allow the sharing of the information.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to share certain personal information of minors with registered entities like employers, educational programs, and workforce boards, but only if the minor's parent or guardian consents. It also streamlines the process for minors to obtain work permits and clarifies conditions under which minors can work in restricted occupations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Minors seeking employment, their parents or guardians, employers, educational institutions, and workforce development organizations in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By simplifying the process for minors to obtain work permits and providing access to relevant information, the bill may help small businesses and organizations employ minors more efficiently, potentially reducing barriers to hiring and failure.

Title: Department of the Environment - Zero-Emission Medium- and Heavy-Duty Vehicles - Regulations (Clean Trucks Act of 2023)
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment to adopt regulations on or before December 1, 2023, establishing requirements for the sale of new zero-emission medium- and heavy-duty vehicles in the State; defining a "heavy-duty vehicle" as one with a gross vehicle weight rating equal to or greater than 14,001 pounds; requiring the Department, in consultation with certain units of State government, to prepare and submit to the General Assembly a certain needs assessment and deployment plan by December 1, 2024; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment to adopt regulations for the sale of new zero-emission medium- and heavy-duty vehicles, establish a needs assessment and deployment plan, and provides grants to support the adoption of such vehicles and equipment, with a focus on reducing emissions and promoting clean transportation.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment, in consultation with the Department of Transportation, the Department of General Services, the Maryland Energy Administration, and the Public Service Commission.
stakeholders: Medium- and heavy-duty vehicle operators, commercial and industrial businesses, environmental groups, and residents in overburdened or underserved communities.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program offers grants that cover up to 75% of the incremental cost of zero-emission vehicles and equipment, which can significantly reduce the financial barriers for small businesses to adopt clean vehicle technology.

Title: Child in Need of Assistance – Neglect – Cannabis Use
Synopsis: Providing that the use of cannabis by a parent or certain other individuals who care for a child does not qualify as neglect except in certain circumstances for purposes of provisions of law relating to children in need of assistance.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies that the use of cannabis by a parent or caregiver does not constitute neglect unless the child's health or mental well-being is harmed or at risk due to cannabis use.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services or local child protective services
stakeholders: Children in care, parents, guardians, and caregivers in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: State Board of Chiropractic Examiners - Disciplinary Actions
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners to take disciplinary action against an applicant or a licensee for failing to comply with a Board order; authorizing the Board to grant a stay of enforcement of a Board order in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act; prohibiting a Board order from being stayed pending judicial review; authorizing the Board to reinstate a suspended or revoked license only in accordance with the terms and conditions of the order or an order of reinstatement issued by the Board; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the disciplinary procedures for the Maryland State Board of Chiropractic Examiners, including clarifying the Board's authority to take disciplinary actions, grant stays, and reinstate licenses.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Chiropractic Examiners
stakeholders: Chiropractors licensed in Maryland and applicants for licensure
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on disciplinary procedures for chiropractors and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Tax Sales - Owner-Occupied Property - Foreclosure, Notice, and Reimbursement of Expenses
Synopsis: Prohibiting in all counties, rather than Baltimore City only, a holder of a certificate of sale from filing a complaint to foreclose the right of redemption for owner-occupied residential property until 9 months from the date of sale; prohibiting in all counties, rather than Baltimore City only, a certain notice from being sent to certain persons with an interest in owner-occupied residential property sold at tax sale until 7 months after the date of sale; etc.
bill_summary: The bill extends the period before a holder of a tax sale certificate can file for foreclosure and send notices for owner-occupied residential properties in all counties of Maryland, not just Baltimore City. It also adjusts the time frame for reimbursement of expenses related to redemption of such properties.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation and local county tax offices.
stakeholders: Homeowners of owner-occupied residential properties who are subject to tax sales, as well as tax sale certificate holders and local government tax offices.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts residential property owners and tax sale certificate holders, with a focus on owner-occupied homes, and does not directly target small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Tax Sales - Homeowner Protection Program - Outreach
Synopsis: Expressing the intent of the General Assembly that at least 2% of the balance in the Homeowner Protection Fund be spent each year to conduct outreach in a certain manner to homeowners in tax sale to encourage the homeowners to enroll in the Homeowner Protection Program; authorizing the State Tax Sale Ombudsman to conduct outreach using State employees and resources or to contract with a private vendor; requiring that certain State and local government agencies provide certain information to facilitate outreach efforts; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Homeowner Protection Program funded by the Homeowner Protection Fund, which includes an outreach campaign to inform homeowners about assistance available when their property is sold at a tax sale. It requires the Department of Assessments and Taxation to contract with a vendor to make live telephone calls to homeowners, providing information and encouraging enrollment in the program.
responsible_party: The Department of Assessments and Taxation, specifically the State Tax Sale Ombudsman and contracted private vendors.
stakeholders: Homeowners whose properties are sold at tax sales in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily targets homeowners at risk of losing their homes due to tax sales, and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Sales and Use Tax Exemption - Redevelopment Areas in Baltimore County - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending, until July 1, 2036, the termination date applicable to an exemption from the sales and use tax for certain construction material or warehousing equipment purchased for use in a certain target redevelopment area in Baltimore County.
bill_summary: The bill extends the expiration date of a sales and use tax exemption for construction materials and warehousing equipment used in certain redevelopment areas in Baltimore County, specifically targeting areas previously owned by Bethlehem Steel and subject to environmental cleanup programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office
stakeholders: Developers and businesses involved in redevelopment projects within the targeted Baltimore County areas, including construction and warehousing companies.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The extension of tax exemptions can reduce costs for businesses involved in redevelopment, potentially lowering the risk of business failure in these projects.

Title: Massage Therapy - Discipline
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners to grant a stay of enforcement of a Board order in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act; prohibiting an order of the Board from being stayed pending judicial review; authorizing the Board to appeal a decision that reverses or modifies its order; altering the grounds for disciplining massage therapists and procedures related to the discipline of massage therapists, including appeals procedures and reinstatement procedures; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates the Maryland Massage Therapy Act to include the professional practice of massage therapy with or without compensation, clarifies disciplinary procedures for massage therapists, and modifies penalties for practicing without a license or making false claims.
responsible_party: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
stakeholders: Licensed massage therapists, massage therapy students, and the general public seeking massage therapy services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for disciplinary procedures and licensing requirements aim to clarify the legal framework, potentially reducing violations and associated failures among small massage therapy businesses.

Title: Accessory Dwelling Unit Policy Task Force
Synopsis: Establishing the Accessory Dwelling Unit Policy Task Force to survey and document a representative sampling of the variety of ordinances, laws, codes, and policies regarding the development and operation of accessory dwelling units in areas zoned for single-family residential use; and requiring the Task Force to report to the Governor and General Assembly on its activities on or before November 1, 2023, and its findings and recommendations on or before June 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Accessory Dwelling Unit Policy Task Force to study efforts to promote the creation of accessory dwelling units on land zoned for single-family residential use, review existing laws and policies, and make recommendations to improve the development and operation of such units.
responsible_party: The Department of Planning, with staff support for the Task Force.
stakeholders: Local governments, residents, homeowners, developers, and community organizations involved in or affected by accessory dwelling units.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to streamline processes and reduce barriers for developing accessory dwelling units, which could support small business growth related to construction, real estate, and property management, thereby potentially reducing small business failure.

Title: Correctional Officers' Retirement System - Special Death Benefits - Applicability
Synopsis: Authorizing an application for special death benefits to be made for the death of certain members of the Correctional Officers' Retirement System.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes a process for surviving spouses of correctional officers who died by homicide in the line of duty on or after June 1, 2001, to apply for and receive special death benefits from the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System, including retroactive payments with interest.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Surviving spouses and families of correctional officers who died in the line of duty by homicide since June 1, 2001
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Massage Therapy - Definition, Registration, and Reimbursement
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "massage therapy"; altering the date after which the option to be registered by the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners to practice massage therapy in a setting that is not a health care setting will no longer be available; and repealing a provision of law that provides that certain provisions of law do not require a nonprofit health insurance plan, an insurer, a health maintenance organization, or a person acting as a third party administrator to reimburse certain individuals for services rendered.
bill_summary: The bill updates the definition of 'massage therapy', sets a deadline for registration options, and repeals certain reimbursement provisions, effectively regulating massage therapy practice and registration in Maryland.
responsible_party: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
stakeholders: Licensed massage therapists, registered massage practitioners, and individuals seeking massage therapy services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's regulation and registration requirements may streamline the industry and reduce legal or operational uncertainties, potentially lowering small business failure rates.

Title: Baltimore City Young Readers Program and Young Readers Matching Grant Program - Alterations (Young Readers Program Act of 2023)
Synopsis: Transferring the Baltimore City Young Readers Program and the Young Readers Matching Grant Program to the Maryland State Library Agency;  requiring program grant applicants to include the distribution of books to children in low-income zip codes within the applicants' areas of service; requiring the Governor to include $350,000 in the annual budget bill for the Program; requiring the State Library Board, beginning December 1, 2024, to report every other year to the General Assembly on the effectiveness of the Program; etc.
bill_summary: The bill expands and alters the Baltimore City Young Readers Program to a statewide initiative, establishing the program within the Maryland State Library Agency. It creates a matching grant program for public libraries and affiliated services to distribute free, high-quality books to children, especially in low-income areas, and allocates funding for these programs.
responsible_party: Maryland State Library Agency
stakeholders: Children in Maryland, especially those in low-income communities, public libraries, and nonprofit organizations involved in distributing books to children.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily supports public libraries and nonprofit organizations, with no direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Estates and Trusts - Registers of Wills - Electronic Filing and Signatures
Synopsis: Requiring a register of wills to accept certain documents filed electronically through a system established by the register of wills; and prohibiting a register of wills from refusing to accept a document based on the manner in which it was signed.
bill_summary: The bill requires registers of wills in Maryland to accept electronic filings of documents, prohibits refusal based on signing method, and allows both electronic and paper filings.
responsible_party: Register of Wills in Maryland
stakeholders: Individuals and entities filing documents with the Register of Wills, including estate and trust stakeholders
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill facilitates electronic filing processes, which can streamline estate management and reduce delays, potentially lowering failure rates for small estate-related businesses.

Title: Minority Business Enterprise Program - Reporting
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to include an attestation that all units required to report are represented in its annual report beginning December 31, 2023; requiring the Office to conduct a certain periodic audit to ensure the accuracy of the attestation; requiring a certain annual report to be submitted to the Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires Maryland state agencies to report annually on their minority business enterprise (MBE) procurement activities, including contract details and participation. It also mandates the Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to attest to the accuracy of these reports, conduct periodic audits, and maintain a list of reporting units.
responsible_party: Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs in the Maryland State government
stakeholders: Minority business enterprises and the agencies that contract with them within Maryland state government
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By increasing transparency and accountability in minority business contracting, the bill aims to support minority businesses and reduce their failure rate.

Title: St. Mary's County - Transfer Tax - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending to October 1, 2028, the authority of the County Commissioners of St. Mary's County to impose a transfer tax on certain instruments of writing.
bill_summary: The bill extends the authority of St. Mary's County to impose a transfer tax on certain instruments of writing until October 1, 2028, instead of the previous expiration date of October 1, 2024.
responsible_party: St. Mary's County Government (County Commissioners)
stakeholders: Property owners and real estate transactions in St. Mary's County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but the extension of transfer tax authority may impact real estate and property transactions in the county.

Title: Baltimore County - Class B-ECF/DS (Education Conference Facility/Dining Service) License - Towson University
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County to issue a Class B-ECF/DS (Education Conference Facility/Dining Service) license for use at certain Towson University events.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Baltimore County to issue a special license allowing Towson University to sell alcohol at university-related events, with specific regulations and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County
stakeholders: Towson University students, staff, and event attendees; university administration; local community
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is specific to a university setting and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Baltimore City - Property Tax - Retroactive Exemption
Synopsis: Authorizing a person who applies for certain property tax exemptions for real property in Baltimore City to request that the exemption be applied retroactively for up to 3 taxable years, subject to certain requirements; requiring Baltimore City and the State to pay a refund of excess real property taxes paid due to a retroactive exemption that is granted; and requiring the Baltimore City Department of Finance to submit a report on the number of requests made and the amounts refunded by December 1 each year from 2023 to 2027.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes property owners in Baltimore City to request retroactive property tax exemptions for up to three years, and requires the city and state to refund any excess taxes paid due to these exemptions. It also establishes reporting requirements and review processes for such requests.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Department of Finance and the Baltimore City Solicitor
stakeholders: Property owners in Baltimore City seeking property tax exemptions
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts property owners and does not directly target small businesses, so its potential to reduce small business failure is minimal.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - Class A-7 Licenses
Synopsis: Repealing certain geographic and temporal restrictions on the issuance of Class A-7 beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Baltimore City.
bill_summary: The bill repeals certain geographic and temporal restrictions on the issuance of Class A–7 alcohol licenses in Baltimore City, allowing more flexibility in licensing and sales hours.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Alcoholic Beverages Board
stakeholders: Alcohol license holders, alcohol consumers, and businesses in Baltimore City
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill potentially reduces barriers for small alcohol retail businesses by expanding licensing opportunities and sales hours.

Title: Environment - On-Farm Composting Facilities - Permit Exemption
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment to adopt regulations to exempt an on-farm composting facility from the requirement to obtain a permit if the on-farm composting facility uses 10,000 square feet of area or less for active food scrap composting, composts only certain materials, records the amount and source of off-site type 2 organics composted and the date and time the off-site type 2 organics arrived on the farm, retains the records for 5 years, provides records on request, and meets any other condition for a permit exemption; etc.
bill_summary: The bill exempts certain on-farm composting facilities from permit requirements if they meet specific size and operational conditions, and mandates the Department of the Environment to adopt regulations for implementing these exemptions and related requirements.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Farmers and farm operators engaging in on-farm composting activities
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides regulatory relief to small farm-based composting operations by exempting qualifying facilities from permit requirements, potentially reducing operational costs and barriers.

Title: Caroline and Queen Anne's Counties - Alcoholic Beverages Licenses - Residency Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring that a certain applicant for an alcoholic beverages license in Caroline County be a resident of the State rather than a resident of the county; and requiring that a certain applicant for an alcoholic beverages license in Queen Anne's County be a resident of the State rather than a resident of the county.
bill_summary: The bill removes the residency requirement for applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses in Caroline and Queen Anne's counties, allowing applicants to be residents of the entire state rather than the specific county.
responsible_party: Maryland State Alcoholic Beverages Administration and local licensing boards in Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.
stakeholders: Applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses, local businesses, and residents of Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By removing the county residency requirement, the bill simplifies the licensing process, potentially reducing barriers for small businesses and encouraging entrepreneurship in these counties.

Title: Maryland Sign Language Interpreters Act
Synopsis: Establishing a licensing and regulatory system for sign language interpreters under the State Board of Sign Language Interpreters in the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing; establishing the Sign Language Interpreters Fund to be used exclusively to cover the documented direct and indirect costs of fulfilling the Board's duties, including development of programs to assist licensure of marginalized interpreters, development of certain mentorship programs, and financial assistance for certain applicants; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a licensing and regulatory system for sign language interpreters in Maryland, including creating a State Board of Sign Language Interpreters, setting licensing requirements, and defining various settings for interpretation services.
responsible_party: The State Board of Sign Language Interpreters within the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing.
stakeholders: Deaf and hard of hearing individuals in Maryland, sign language interpreters, and organizations providing interpretation services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to professionalize and regulate sign language interpreters, which could improve the stability and success of interpretation businesses by establishing clear licensing standards and a formal regulatory framework.

Title: Eligible Projects - Procurement of Construction Materials (Buy Clean Maryland Act)
Synopsis: Requiring producers of any cement or concrete mixture used in the construction of an eligible project to submit environmental product declarations to the Department of General Services by December 31, 2024; requiring the Department to establish a maximum acceptable global warming potential for certain categories of eligible materials by January 1, 2026; establishing an Environmental Product Declaration Assistance Fund to support the development of certain environmental product declarations; etc.
bill_summary: The Buy Clean Maryland Act requires the use of environmentally friendly materials in public construction projects, establishing maximum global warming potential limits for certain materials, and mandates reporting and transparency in environmental impacts of construction materials.
responsible_party: Department of General Services and Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Producers of eligible construction materials, state government agencies, contractors, and the public involved in or affected by public construction projects in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to promote sustainable construction practices and transparency, which could encourage innovation and market growth for low-carbon materials, potentially reducing small business failures related to environmental compliance and market competitiveness.

Title: Abandoned Vehicles - Secured Parties - Electronic Notification
Synopsis: Authorizing a police department that takes an abandoned vehicle into custody to notify any secured party electronically if that form of notice is agreed to by the police department, the tower, and the secured party in a certain manner; and altering the application of a provision of law authorizing a police department to provide certain alternative public notice of custody of an abandoned vehicle to include circumstances where electronic notice is unacknowledged or undeliverable.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes police departments in Maryland to notify secured parties electronically about abandoned vehicles, if all parties agree, and updates procedures for public notice when electronic notice is unacknowledged or undeliverable.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation or local police departments responsible for vehicle impoundment and notification.
stakeholders: Vehicle owners, secured parties (such as lenders or lienholders), and police departments involved in vehicle impoundment.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for electronic notification and clear procedures may streamline processes for secured parties, potentially reducing delays and costs associated with abandoned vehicle cases, which could help small businesses involved in vehicle financing or related services.

Title: St. Mary's County - Gaming - Senior Activity Centers
Synopsis: Authorizing a certain senior activity center to conduct gaming events, bunco games, and card games in St. Mary's County; prohibiting a senior activity center in St. Mary's County from awarding prize money in excess of $50 to a winner in each session or charging a participant more than $25 to play one session; requiring any money that remains after prizes are awarded to be used to support future programming at the senior activity center; etc.
bill_summary: The bill allows senior activity centers in St. Mary's County to conduct gaming events, bunco games, and card games with specific limitations on prizes and charges, and requires any remaining money after prizes are awarded to be used for future programming.
responsible_party: St. Mary's County Senior Activity Centers and local government authorities
stakeholders: Senior citizens participating in the senior activity centers in St. Mary's County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is focused on senior activity centers and gaming events, not on small businesses, so it is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Family Law - Maryland Child Abduction Prevention Act
Synopsis: Authorizing a court to order child abduction prevention measures if the court finds there is a credible risk of abduction of the child; authorizing certain parties to petition the court for child abduction prevention measures; requiring a petition to be verified, include a copy of any existing child custody determination, and specify the risk factors for abduction; requiring the court to consider certain evidence of a credible risk of abduction; establishing requirements for an abduction prevention order; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Child Abduction Prevention Act, which authorizes courts to require notice of international travel with a child, and to issue child abduction prevention measures including orders, warrants, and restrictions to prevent child abduction in custody disputes.
responsible_party: Maryland courts and law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Parents involved in custody disputes, children, and family law courts in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill primarily focuses on child custody and abduction prevention measures and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: 9–8–8 Trust Fund – Funding
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget bill for fiscal year 2025 an appropriation of $12,000,000 to the 9-8-8 Trust Fund for the purpose of designating and maintaining 9-8-8 as the universal telephone number for a national suicide prevention and mental health crisis hotline and for developing and implementing a statewide initiative for the coordination and delivery of behavioral health crisis response services in the State.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the 9–8–8 Trust Fund in Maryland to fund the national suicide prevention and mental health crisis hotline, as well as statewide behavioral health crisis response services. It requires the Governor to allocate $12 million to the fund in fiscal year 2025.
responsible_party: The Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals experiencing mental health or behavioral health crises in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Health Occupations - Environmental Health Specialists - Revisions
Synopsis: Altering the education requirements for an applicant for licensure as an environmental health specialist; altering the grounds for which the Board may take disciplinary action against an applicant or a licensee to include misfeasance and malfeasance while performing the duties of an environmental health specialist; etc.
bill_summary: The bill revises the education requirements, examination procedures, disciplinary actions, and review processes for environmental health specialists in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Environmental Health Specialists
stakeholders: Environmental health specialists and the public they serve in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for examination and licensing are unlikely to have a significant impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Education - Libraries - Funding
Synopsis: Providing certain funding for each county public library system for fiscal year 2028 and each fiscal year thereafter.
bill_summary: The bill increases funding for Maryland's public library systems, providing specific per-resident funding amounts for each fiscal year from 2011 through 2027 and beyond, with the state sharing approximately 40% of the total cost and counties covering at least 20%.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education or the Maryland State Library Agency
stakeholders: Public library users and residents of Maryland counties
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates; it focuses on library funding.

Title: Montgomery County – Alcoholic Beverages – Holders of Class B–BWL (Clubhouse/Lodge) License and Class 7 Micro–Brewery License MC 16–23
Synopsis: Providing that the restriction on holding or having a financial interest in other retail alcoholic beverages licenses for holders of a Class 7 micro-brewery license does not apply to a holder of a Class B-BWL (clubhouse/lodge) license in Montgomery County who is issued a Class 7 micro-brewery license.
bill_summary: The bill allows holders of a Class B–BWL (clubhouse/lodge) license in Montgomery County to also hold a Class 7 micro–brewery license without the usual restriction that limits micro–brewery license holders from having other retail alcohol licenses.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Revenue Authority and the Alcoholic Beverages Commission
stakeholders: Owners and operators of clubhouses, lodges, micro–breweries, and related alcohol license holders in Montgomery County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill potentially reduces barriers for micro–brewery and clubhouse/lodge license holders, which could help small businesses expand and operate more effectively.

Title: Health Occupations - Clinical Nurse Specialists - Prescribing
Synopsis: Defining "clinical nurse specialist" and "practice as a clinical nurse specialist" for the purpose of authorizing clinical nurse specialists to prescribe drugs and durable medical equipment under regulations adopted by the State Board of Nursing; designating a clinical nurse specialist as an "authorized prescriber" under the Maryland Pharmacy Act; and authorizing a licensed physician to personally prepare and dispense a prescription written by a clinical nurse specialist.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes clinical nurse specialists to prescribe drugs and durable medical equipment under regulations adopted by the State Board of Nursing, and includes them as authorized prescribers under the Maryland Pharmacy Act. It also allows licensed physicians to personally prepare and dispense prescriptions written by clinical nurse specialists.
responsible_party: State Board of Nursing and licensed physicians in Maryland
stakeholders: Clinical nurse specialists, physicians, and patients in Maryland who will benefit from expanded prescribing authority and improved healthcare access.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions are unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates, as it primarily pertains to healthcare practice regulations.

Title: Prescription Drug Affordability Board - Upper Payment Limits
Synopsis: Reestablishing the requirement that the Prescription Drug Affordability Board, under certain circumstances, draft a plan of action for implementing a process to set upper payment limits for certain prescription drug products; reestablishing the authority of the Board to set upper payments limits, under certain circumstances, for prescription drug products that are purchased or paid for by or through certain State or local government entities, plans, or programs; etc.
bill_summary: The bill reestablishes and expands the authority of the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board to set upper payment limits for certain prescription drugs that cause affordability issues, including a process for drafting plans, monitoring drug availability, and handling appeals.
responsible_party: Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board
stakeholders: Consumers, patients, and healthcare payers in Maryland, especially those affected by high drug costs and shortages.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to reduce the financial burden of prescription drug costs, which could help small businesses by lowering healthcare expenses and improving employee access to affordable medication.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program - Gender-Affirming Treatment (Trans Health Equity Act)
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning on January 1, 2024, the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide gender-affirming treatment in a nondiscriminatory manner; requiring that the gender-affirming treatment be assessed according to nondiscriminatory criteria that are consistent with current clinical standards; prohibiting the issuance of an adverse benefit determination related to gender-affirming treatment unless a certain experienced health care provider has reviewed and confirmed the appropriateness of the determination; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program to provide medically necessary gender-affirming treatment in a nondiscriminatory manner starting January 1, 2024. It defines gender-affirming treatment, mandates coverage based on current clinical standards, and prohibits denial or limitation of such treatments unless reviewed and confirmed by an experienced healthcare provider.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Managed Care Organizations
stakeholders: Transgender, nonbinary, intersex, two-spirit, and other gender-diverse individuals enrolled in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts healthcare providers offering gender-affirming treatments and the Maryland Department of Health, with indirect effects on small healthcare businesses by clarifying coverage and reporting requirements.

Title: Grocery Stores and Restaurants - Automated External Defibrillator Program (Joe Sheya Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the owners and operators of grocery stores with annual gross incomes greater than $10,000,000 or restaurants with annual gross incomes of more than $1,000,000, beginning on January 1, 2024, to place an automated external defibrillator in a prominent, accessible area and maintain the functionality of the defibrillator; and requiring the Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems jointly to adopt certain regulations.
bill_summary: The bill requires owners and operators of certain grocery stores and restaurants in Maryland to implement automated external defibrillator (AED) programs, including placing AEDs in accessible areas and maintaining their functionality, starting from January 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
stakeholders: Grocery stores and restaurants in Maryland, their employees, and customers
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program is designed to improve emergency response and safety, which could reduce liabilities and improve community trust, potentially lowering failure rates for small businesses.

Title: Maryland Forestry Education Fund - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Forestry Education Fund to expand and enhance the Maryland Forestry Foundation's capacity to provide certain education and resources to forest landowners, the ability of district forestry boards and the knowledge of local governments to achieve healthy and sustainable forests, and the ability of businesses to test innovative best management practices in forestry; and requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget bill $250,000 for the Fund in fiscal years 2025 and 2026.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Forestry Education Fund to support education, outreach, and testing of innovative forestry practices, with funding from state appropriations, interest earnings, and other sources. It aims to promote sustainable forest management and support forest landowners, local governments, and businesses.
responsible_party: The Maryland Forestry Foundation
stakeholders: Forest landowners, district forestry boards, local governments, businesses involved in forestry, and the general public interested in forest sustainability.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides grants and support for businesses to test innovative forestry management practices, which could help reduce small business failures related to forestry practices.

Title: Public Health - Dental Services - Access
Synopsis: Altering the Maryland Dent-Care Program; establishing a requirement regarding the reimbursement of dental-related services under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program; establishing requirements on the Maryland Department of Health regarding the creation and distribution of plain language materials related to dental services; requiring the State Board of Dental Examiners to publish a searchable list of licensed providers who provide mobile dental services or portable dental services in the State; etc.
bill_summary: The bill aims to improve access to dental services for children and underserved populations in Maryland by requiring dental screenings at certain ages, establishing the Maryland Dent–Care Program to support dental professionals serving Medicaid recipients, creating plain language dental information, and studying ways to increase dental provider participation and service delivery.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland State Board of Dental Examiners
stakeholders: Children enrolled in Maryland public schools, children in child care, dental providers, Medicaid recipients, underserved Maryland residents, and pregnant women.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill includes provisions to support dental providers, including a grant or loan program for providers in underserved areas and incentives to increase participation, which could help reduce small business failure in the dental sector.

Title: Health Occupations - Clinical and Graduate Alcohol and Drug Counselors - Licensure
Synopsis: Altering the educational requirements that individuals must meet to be licensed as clinical or graduate alcohol and drug counselors.
bill_summary: The bill updates the educational and licensing requirements for clinical and graduate alcohol and drug counselors in Maryland, including provisions for licensure waivers and supervised practice.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Examiners of Alcohol and Drug Counselors
stakeholders: Individuals seeking licensure as alcohol and drug counselors, including recent graduates and licensed professionals from other jurisdictions.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill may facilitate the licensing process for professionals, potentially reducing barriers for new counselors and supporting small counseling practices, but it does not explicitly target small business failure.

Title: Child Care Providers - Registration and Licensing - Exemptions
Synopsis: Exempting certain family child care homes, large family child care homes, and child care centers that serve only dependent children of military personnel and are located on a military base or federal property or are certified as a family child care provider by a branch of the U.S. Department of Defense or the Coast Guard from certain registration and licensing requirements; authorizing certain entities to assume responsibility for approving or determining which children may be served by exempted child care providers; etc.
bill_summary: The bill exempts certain family child care homes, large family child care homes, and child care centers serving only dependent children of military personnel on federal property or certified by the U.S. Department of Defense or Coast Guard from Maryland's registration and licensing requirements, and authorizes military and federal agencies to oversee these providers.
responsible_party: U.S. Department of Defense, U.S. Coast Guard, Maryland Department of Health, local health officers, county departments of education, Department of Human Services, and local departments.
stakeholders: Dependent children of military personnel, military families, child care providers on federal property, and the agencies overseeing child care.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill could reduce the regulatory burden on certain child care providers, potentially decreasing failure rates among these providers by simplifying licensing requirements.

Title: Criminal Law - Victims of Child Sex Trafficking and Human Trafficking - Safe Harbor and Service Response
Synopsis: Altering procedures that a law enforcement officer and a court are required to follow when the law enforcement officer or court has reason to believe that a child who has been detained is a victim of sex trafficking or a victim of human trafficking; providing that a minor may not be criminally prosecuted or proceeded against under certain provisions of law for a certain offense if the minor committed the offense as a direct result of being a victim of sex trafficking or being a victim of human trafficking; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland laws to improve the response to child victims of sex trafficking and human trafficking. It establishes procedures for law enforcement and courts to identify victims, prevent their criminal prosecution for offenses committed as a result of trafficking, and ensure appropriate service responses.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services and the judiciary system, including law enforcement agencies and courts.
stakeholders: Children and minors who are victims of sex trafficking or human trafficking in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but it may indirectly support victims who are small business owners or involved in small businesses by providing protections and services.

Title: Public Health - Rare Disease Advisory Council
Synopsis: Establishing the Rare Disease Advisory Council to study and make recommendations on matters relating to individuals with rare diseases in the State; requiring the Council to convene public hearings, make inquiries, and solicit comments from the public on the needs of rare disease patients, caregivers, and health care providers; requiring the Council to report to the Governor and General Assembly by December 1 each year beginning in 2024 and to provide recommendations on ways to address the needs of persons with rare diseases in the State; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Rare Disease Advisory Council in Maryland to study issues related to individuals with rare diseases and make policy recommendations to improve their care, access, and treatment.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health, which shall provide staff for the council.
stakeholders: Individuals with rare diseases, their caregivers, healthcare providers, researchers, and related organizations in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve healthcare and support systems for rare disease patients, which could indirectly help small healthcare-related businesses, but it does not directly target small business failure.

Title: State Employee Rights and Protections - Personnel Actions and Harassment - Complaints
Synopsis: Authorizing an applicant for State employment or a State employee to file a complaint alleging harassment by an employer within 2 years after the alleged violation that is the basis of the complaint; and increasing, from 30 days to 1 year, the period of time for an applicant or employee to file a complaint alleging certain prohibited personnel actions.
bill_summary: The bill extends the time period for employees or applicants to file complaints about harassment or prohibited personnel actions, increasing the filing window from 30 days to 1 year for violations related to harassment, and clarifies procedures for filing complaints against harassment by employers.
responsible_party: State Department of Human Resources or equivalent state agency responsible for employee protections and workplace conduct.
stakeholders: State employees and applicants for employment within Maryland government agencies.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts state employment practices and does not directly relate to small business operations or failure rates.

Title: Income Tax Checkoff - Maryland Veterans Trust Fund
Synopsis: Establishing a certain income tax checkoff for voluntary contributions to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund; requiring the Comptroller to include certain information in each individual income tax return package; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a voluntary income tax checkoff for contributions to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund, allowing taxpayers to donate part of their tax refund or owed amount to support veterans and their families.
responsible_party: The Comptroller of Maryland is responsible for implementing the program, including including the checkoff on tax forms and collecting contributions.
stakeholders: Veterans and their families in Maryland, as well as organizations supporting veterans.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program is unlikely to have a significant direct impact on reducing small business failure rates, as it primarily involves individual contributions through tax filings.

Title: Pesticides - PFAS Testing - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Agriculture, in consultation with certain State and federal agencies, to study the use of perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) in pesticides in the State; and requiring the Department to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor, the Senate Committee on Education, Energy, and the Environment, and the House Health and Government Operations Committee on or before November 1, 2023.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits the registration of pesticides for use against mosquitoes in Maryland unless the distributor submits PFAS test results and an affidavit verifying the results.
