It also requires a study on the use of PFAS in pesticides, including health and environmental impacts, testing methods, and regulatory efforts, with a report due by November 1, 2023.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture, in consultation with the Department of the Environment, the Maryland Department of Health, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
stakeholders: Pesticide manufacturers, distributors, and users, as well as residents and the environment in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's requirements for PFAS testing and affidavits could increase compliance costs for small pesticide businesses, potentially impacting their failure rates.

Title: Maryland Longitudinal Data System - Definition of Student Data - Alteration
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "student data" for purposes of the Maryland Longitudinal Data System to include student disability data by specific disability category.
bill_summary: The bill amends the Maryland Longitudinal Data System to include student disability data categorized by specific disability types in the definition of 'student data'.
responsible_party: Maryland Longitudinal Data System Center
stakeholders: Students with disabilities and educational institutions in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Cigarette Restitution Fund - Payments for Sale and Marketing of Electronic Smoking Devices - Use
Synopsis: Requiring the Cigarette Restitution Fund to include a separate account consisting of payments received by the State from certain enforcement actions related to the sale and marketing of electronic smoking devices; and providing that distributions from the separate account may be used, consistent with any other State law, to supplement General Fund appropriations designated for certain programs with the purpose of reducing the use of tobacco products by individuals under 21 years of age.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a separate account within the Cigarette Restitution Fund to hold payments received from litigation related to the sale and marketing of electronic smoking devices. Funds from this account will be used to support programs aimed at reducing tobacco use among individuals under 21, including education, prevention, and enforcement efforts.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Health and other relevant state agencies involved in tobacco control and public health programs.
stakeholders: Young individuals under the age of 21, public health organizations, tobacco control programs, and the general Maryland population.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on funding tobacco prevention and control programs, not directly on small businesses, so its impact on small business failure rates is likely minimal.

Title: Public Health - Home- and Community-Based Services for Children and Youth
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health to expand access to and provide reimbursement for intensive in-home services, case management, and wraparound services; requiring, beginning in fiscal year 2024, the Behavioral Health Administration to fund 100 slots in the mental health case management program for children or youth at risk of out-of-home placement who are not eligible for program services; requiring the Governor to include funding in the annual budget bill for customized goods and services for certain youth; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to expand access to and reimburse for home- and community-based mental health services for children and youth, including wraparound, intensive in-home, and case management services. It also mandates funding, reporting, and stakeholder consultation to improve these services.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children and youth with mental health needs and their families in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve mental health service delivery for children and youth, which may indirectly support small businesses involved in providing these services, but it does not explicitly target small business failure reduction.

Title: Social Services Programs - Eligibility and Enrollment
Synopsis: Requiring the Office of Home Energy Programs to enroll households, based on certain eligibility, in any fuel and utility assistance program; and altering the eligibility requirements for the electric universal service program to provide assistance to customers with annual incomes at or below 200% of the federal poverty level.
bill_summary: The bill updates eligibility and enrollment procedures for social services programs in Maryland, including the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, the Office of Home Energy Programs, and the electric universal service program, to improve access and support for low-income and vulnerable populations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services and the Office of Home Energy Programs
stakeholders: Low-income individuals and families, elderly, households with children, and vulnerable populations in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily targets social service programs for individuals and households, and does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Provision of Veterinary Services - Practice of Veterinary Medicine and Rabies Vaccines
Synopsis: Authorizing the State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners to issue a license to an animal control facility to administer rabies vaccines; requiring the Board to establish an expedited process to authorize a veterinary practitioner who holds a current, valid license to practice veterinary medicine in another state or jurisdiction to become licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the State; requiring the Secretary of Health to allow certain veterinary technicians or other clinical staff to administer rabies vaccines; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners to issue licenses to animal control facilities to administer rabies vaccines and allows certain veterinary practitioners licensed in other states to provide routine medical care in Maryland. It also establishes protocols for administering rabies vaccines by trained staff in veterinary hospitals and animal shelters.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners and the Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Veterinary practitioners, animal shelters, animal control facilities, and animals in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to streamline licensing and operational procedures for veterinary services and animal shelters, potentially reducing barriers and costs, which could help small veterinary practices and shelters avoid failure.

Title: State Finance and Procurement - Grants - Prompt Payment Requirement
Synopsis: Establishing invoicing and prompt payment requirements for certain State grants; requiring the State to make payment under certain grant agreements within 37 days of the payment becoming due under the agreement or after receiving a proper invoice; and authorizing interest accrual at the rate of 9% per year on any amount that is due and payable but remains unpaid after a certain time.
bill_summary: This bill establishes invoicing and prompt payment requirements for certain state grants, including deadlines for payments and interest on late payments.
responsible_party: State grant-making entities and the Office of the Comptroller of Maryland
stakeholders: Organizations receiving state grants, including nonprofits and other non-state entities
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for timely payments and interest on late payments aim to improve cash flow for grant recipients, potentially reducing financial stress and failure risk.

Title: Hospitals - Financial Assistance - Medical Bill Reimbursement Process
Synopsis: Establishing requirements related to the reimbursement of out-of-pocket costs paid by certain hospital patients who were eligible for free care, including requirements related to the consideration of data and the reporting and disclosure of certain information; authorizing the Commission to impose a fine of up to $50,000 per violation if a hospital fails to provide refunds to qualifying patients; making a violation of the Act an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice subject to penalties under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a process for reimbursing hospital patients who paid out-of-pocket costs for services they may have qualified for free care, based on income and eligibility data. It also modifies how hospitals identify and reimburse these patients, and requires reporting and data sharing among state agencies.
responsible_party: The Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission, in coordination with the Department of Health, the Department of Human Services, the Office of the Comptroller, the Department of Education, and the Maryland Hospital Association.
stakeholders: Hospital patients who paid out-of-pocket costs and may have been eligible for free care, hospitals, and state agencies involved in healthcare and social services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on healthcare reimbursement processes and data sharing, which are not directly related to small business failure reduction.

Title: Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission - Reporting and Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Extending the time for the submission of the final report of the Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission to December 1, 2025; and extending the termination date for the Commission to June 30, 2026.
bill_summary: The bill extends the deadline for the Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission to submit its final report to December 1, 2025, and extends the commission's termination date to June 30, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Lynching Truth and Reconciliation Commission
stakeholders: Maryland residents, historians, and communities affected by lynching history
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Montgomery County - Alcohol Beverage Services - Advisory Board MC 04-23
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Advisory Board of the Alcohol Beverage Services of Montgomery County to include a designee of the Director of the Services and a designee of the Director of the Montgomery County Department of Police.
bill_summary: The bill amends the composition of the Advisory Board of the Alcohol Beverage Services of Montgomery County to include a designee of the Director of the Services and a designee of the Director of the Montgomery County Department of Police.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Alcohol Beverage Services and Montgomery County Department of Police
stakeholders: Residents of Montgomery County, alcohol beverage service providers, law enforcement agencies, and local government officials.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure or include programs aimed at reducing small business failure rates.

Title: Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders - Funding - Repeal of Sunset
Synopsis: Repealing the termination date of certain provisions of law requiring the Comptroller to distribute a certain amount of certain abandoned property funds to the Tax Clinics for Low-Income Marylanders Fund which provides grants to the University of Maryland School of Law, the University of Baltimore School of Law, and the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service to operate tax clinics for low-income Maryland residents.
bill_summary: The bill extends funding for tax clinics for low-income Marylanders by repealing the sunset clause, ensuring continued financial support through the Tax Clinics for Low–Income Marylanders Fund, and clarifies the distribution of funds from abandoned property proceeds to support legal services and tax clinics.
responsible_party: The Comptroller of Maryland, in conjunction with the University of Maryland School of Law, the University of Baltimore School of Law, and the Maryland Volunteer Lawyers Service.
stakeholders: Low-income Maryland residents who benefit from free tax assistance and legal services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's funding for tax clinics helps low-income individuals access tax and legal assistance, which can improve their financial stability and reduce the likelihood of business failure among small businesses owned by or serving these populations.

Title: Baltimore County - School Board Nominating Commission - Vacancy Procedures
Synopsis: Requiring the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission to hold a public hearing on the selection of a nominee for a single vacancy on the Baltimore County Board of Education in a certain manner under certain circumstances; requiring the Commission to make publicly available on its website live video streaming of certain public hearings and certain archived video recordings; and authorizing the Commission to retain and reactivate the applications of certain candidates for certain vacancies on the county board.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission to hold public hearings, stream live video, and make recordings available online when selecting nominees for the Baltimore County Board of Education. It also details the composition, appointment process, and reactivation of candidate applications for the commission.
responsible_party: Baltimore County School Board Nominating Commission and Baltimore County Public Schools
stakeholders: Residents of Baltimore County, including students, parents, educators, and community organizations involved in the school system.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on school board nomination procedures.

Title: Maryland School for the Blind - Public School Construction Program - Eligibility
Synopsis: Repealing the termination date on the eligibility of the Maryland School for the Blind for funding under the Public School Construction Program.
bill_summary: The bill removes the previous deadline that limited funding eligibility for the Maryland School for the Blind under the Public School Construction Program, allowing it to continue receiving funding.
responsible_party: Interagency Commission on School Construction
stakeholders: Students and staff at the Maryland School for the Blind, and the Maryland Department of Education
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to school construction funding for a specific school.

Title: 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion Day
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor annually to proclaim March 9 as 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion Day in recognition of the service of the women of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion during World War II.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Governor of Maryland to annually proclaim March 9 as 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion Day to honor the service of women in the battalion during World War II.
responsible_party: Governor of Maryland
stakeholders: Members of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion, Maryland residents, history and military communities
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Recordation Tax - Indemnity Mortgage Exemption - Threshold Amount
Synopsis: Altering the threshold amount for certain indemnity mortgage transactions that are exempt from the recordation tax from less than $3,000,000 to less than $12,500,000; and applying the Act to instruments of writing recorded on or after July 1, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill increases the threshold amount for indemnity mortgage transactions that are exempt from the Maryland recordation tax, allowing more transactions to qualify for exemption. It also authorizes local governments to grant exemptions for certain indemnity mortgages and requires reporting on these exemptions and their impact on revenue.
responsible_party: The Maryland State and local government agencies, specifically the Maryland Department of Assessments and Taxation and local county and Baltimore City officials responsible for recordation tax collection.
stakeholders: Mortgage lenders, property owners, and local governments involved in real estate transactions in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's increased exemption threshold may reduce costs for property transactions, potentially easing financial burdens on small businesses involved in real estate.

Title: Higher Education – Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship – Altering Name of Scholarship
Synopsis: Altering the name of the Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship to be the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship.
bill_summary: The bill renames the existing Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship to the Douglas J. J. Peters Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq Conflicts Scholarship and establishes a dedicated fund for it, managed by the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Veterans of the Afghanistan and Iraq conflicts seeking higher education scholarships in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Health Insurance – Pharmacy Benefits Managers – Audits of Pharmacies and Pharmacists
Synopsis: Requiring the Secretary of Health to adopt regulations for pharmacy benefits managers that contract with managed care organizations that establish requirements for conducting audits of pharmacies or pharmacists; establishing requirements and prohibitions regarding audits by certain pharmacy benefits managers, including provisions related to audit limits, acceptance of certain documents as proof, recoupment of funds or charging of fees for prescriptions of unbreakable package sizes, and access to financial documentation; etc.
bill_summary: The bill expands regulations and requirements for pharmacy benefits managers (PBMs) conducting audits of pharmacies and pharmacists, including registration of auditing entities, notification procedures, audit standards, and dispute resolution processes, to improve transparency and fairness.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner and the Secretary of Health
stakeholders: Pharmacies, pharmacists, and consumers in Maryland who are affected by pharmacy audits and reimbursements.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to improve the fairness and transparency of pharmacy audits, which could reduce unnecessary financial burdens on small pharmacies and pharmacists, potentially decreasing their failure rate.

Title: Health Insurance - Diagnostic and Supplemental Examinations and Biopsies for Breast Cancer - Cost-Sharing
Synopsis: Prohibiting, except under certain circumstances, insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations that provide coverage for diagnostic and supplemental breast examinations from imposing a copayment, coinsurance, or deductible requirement for the examination; and requiring the Maryland Health Care Commission to study and report to the Governor and certain committees of the General Assembly by October 1, 2023 on the financial impact of eliminating cost-sharing for diagnostic image-guided biopsies for breast cancer.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits health insurance providers in Maryland from charging copayments, coinsurance, or deductibles for diagnostic and supplemental breast examinations, including image-guided biopsies, with certain exceptions. It also requires a study on the financial impact of eliminating cost-sharing for biopsies.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Care Commission
stakeholders: Individuals undergoing breast cancer screening and diagnosis, particularly those at increased risk, and health insurance providers in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: By reducing or eliminating cost-sharing for breast cancer diagnostic procedures, the bill may lower financial barriers for patients, potentially leading to earlier detection and treatment, which can improve health outcomes and reduce long-term costs.

Title: Montgomery County - Village of Friendship Heights Special Taxing District - Procurement MC 15-23
Synopsis: Increasing the threshold amount above which the Friendship Heights Village Council is prohibited from entering into a certain contract without a competitive bidding process; and authorizing the village council, by majority vote, to enter into a certain contract that exceeds the $20,000 threshold amount without a competitive bidding process if the procurement is in response to an emergency.
bill_summary: The bill increases the contract threshold for the Friendship Heights Village Council from $5,000 to $20,000 and allows the council to bypass competitive bidding in emergency situations.
responsible_party: Friendship Heights Village Council
stakeholders: Residents and businesses within the Village of Friendship Heights in Montgomery County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill may streamline procurement processes, potentially reducing delays and administrative burdens for small businesses involved in village contracts.

Title: Commissioner of Financial Regulation - Name and Organization of Office
Synopsis: Establishing the name of a certain office under the Commissioner of Financial Regulation in the Maryland Department of Labor as the Office of Financial Regulation; designating a certain appointee of the Commissioner of Financial Regulation as the Deputy Commissioner for Depository Activities; requiring the Commissioner of Financial Regulation to appoint a Deputy Commissioner for Non-Depository Activities; etc.
bill_summary: The bill renames the Office of the Commissioner of Financial Regulation in the Maryland Department of Labor to the Office of Financial Regulation, establishes a Deputy Commissioner for Depository Activities and a Deputy Commissioner for Non-Depository Activities, and clarifies organizational and staffing provisions for the office.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor, Office of Financial Regulation
stakeholders: Financial institutions, credit unions, check cashing service providers, and individuals involved in financial regulation in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions for licensing, regulation, and oversight aim to strengthen financial stability and compliance, which can help reduce small business failures related to financial mismanagement or non-compliance.

Title: Maryland Department of Health and Prescription Drug Affordability Board - Managed Care Organizations and Prescription Drug Claims - Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health and the Prescription Drug Affordability Board jointly to study certain information regarding the payment of prescription drug claims under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program during calendar years 2021 and 2022 and how to address certain inconsistencies; and requiring the Department and the Board to report the findings of the study to the Maryland Medicaid Administration and certain committees of the General Assembly by October 31, 2023.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health and the Prescription Drug Affordability Board to study and address inconsistencies in how prescription drug claims are reimbursed under the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and managed care organizations, including analyzing payment amounts and recommending methodologies for determining drug costs and dispensing fees.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Prescription Drug Affordability Board
stakeholders: Pharmacies, managed care organizations, prescription drug providers, and Medicaid recipients in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to standardize reimbursement rates for pharmacies, which could reduce financial uncertainties and improve stability for small pharmacies, potentially decreasing their failure rate.

Title: Institutions of Higher Education - Transcripts - Prohibition on Punitive Measures Related to Student Debt
Synopsis: Prohibiting an institution of higher education from refusing to provide a current or former student with a transcript or taking other punitive measures regarding a student's transcript request because the student owes a debt to the institution of higher education.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits Maryland higher education institutions from refusing, delaying, or charging extra fees for transcripts or taking punitive actions against students who owe debts to the institution.
responsible_party: Institutions of Higher Education in Maryland
stakeholders: Current and former students of Maryland higher education institutions who may owe debts
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to higher education transcript policies.

Title: Natural Resources - Blue and Flathead Catfish Finfish Trotline License - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing a licensing and regulatory scheme to allow the commercial fishing of blue and flathead catfish in the tidal waters of the State using a finfish trotline.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a licensing program for the commercial fishing of blue and flathead catfish in Maryland's tidal waters using finfish trotlines, including setting the license fee and regulations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Commercial fishers targeting blue and flathead catfish in Maryland's tidal waters
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides a low-cost, streamlined licensing process for commercial fishers, which could help reduce barriers to entry and support small fishing businesses.

Title: Bond Sales - Notification of the Public
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of Public Works and the State Treasurer to provide public notice of a public sale of State bonds by The Municipal Market Monitor (TM3) or a similar service or such other method deemed appropriate by the State Treasurer.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Board of Public Works and the State Treasurer to provide public notice of State bond sales through a service or method deemed appropriate, such as the Municipal Market Monitor (TM3). It establishes requirements for advance notice and procedures for postponing bond sales.
responsible_party: Maryland State Treasurer and the Board of Public Works
stakeholders: Investors, financial institutions, and the general public interested in Maryland State bond sales
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small businesses or their failure rates; it focuses on public notification procedures for State bond sales.

Title: Department of Agriculture - State Specialist for Value-Added Agriculture
Synopsis: Establishing the State Specialist for Value-Added Agriculture as a position in the Department of Agriculture to serve as the primary point of contact for individuals engaging in, or interested in engaging in, value-added agriculture in the State; and requiring the Specialist to provide information regarding State and federal regulations related to value-added agriculture and to act as a liaison between State and federal partners involved in value-added agriculture.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the position of the State Specialist for Value–Added Agriculture within the Maryland Department of Agriculture. This role serves as a primary contact and liaison for individuals involved in value-added agriculture, providing information on regulations and supporting the development of this sector.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
stakeholders: Farmers, producers, processors, and businesses involved in value-added agriculture in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The program aims to support value-added agricultural businesses by providing guidance and acting as a liaison, which could help reduce business failures in this sector.

Title: Vehicle Laws - Parking Enforcement - Citations
Synopsis: Requiring a parking citation issued by a political subdivision, a State agency, or a third-party contractor to include a box that the person issued the citation may check to indicate that the registration plates cited were not issued for the vehicle described in the citation; requiring a political subdivision, State agency, or third-party contractor that receives a parking citation from a person with the box checked to perform a certain verification process and dismiss the citation under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires parking citations issued by Maryland authorities or contractors to include a checkbox allowing the recipient to indicate that the cited registration plates do not belong to the vehicle. If checked, the issuing agency must verify the claim and potentially dismiss the citation.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies, political subdivisions, or third-party contractors involved in parking enforcement.
stakeholders: Vehicle owners and drivers in Maryland who receive parking citations.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to reduce unnecessary citations and related disputes, which could lower administrative burdens and costs for enforcement agencies and vehicle owners, potentially reducing small business failures related to parking enforcement issues.

Title: Maryland Tort Claims Act - Denial of Claims - Notice
Synopsis: Altering the means by which the State Treasurer may send notice of a denial of a claim made under the Maryland Tort Claims Act to authorize notice by e-mail or, if it is the only available means, by regular mail.
bill_summary: The bill amends the Maryland Tort Claims Act to allow the State Treasurer to send notice of claim denial via email or, if email is unavailable, by regular mail, instead of certified mail.
responsible_party: Maryland State Treasurer's Office
stakeholders: Claimants under the Maryland Tort Claims Act, including individuals and entities filing claims against the state
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily affects claim notification procedures and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: State Government - State Facilities Changes and Closures - Procedures
Synopsis: Requiring a principal department of the Executive Branch to give certain notice to the public, the General Assembly, and any exclusive representative with certain bargaining unit employees, hold a public hearing, submit a certain report, make the report publicly available, and allow the submission of certain comments before changing the use, purpose, or function of a State facility or closing a State facility.
bill_summary: The bill establishes procedures that a principal department of the Maryland State government must follow before changing the use, purpose, or function of a State facility or closing a State facility, including public hearings and notices.
responsible_party: Principal departments of the Maryland State government
stakeholders: State employees, clients, inmates, residents, and the general public affected by State facility changes or closures
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: State Investment Portfolio - Investment Thresholds - Alterations
Synopsis: Repealing the limitations on investment in certain commercial paper in which the Treasurer may invest or reinvest certain unexpended or surplus funds; requiring the Treasurer to adopt regulations to establish a State investment policy with certain thresholds; and requiring the Treasurer to notify certain officials and governing bodies of certain local governmental units about the provisions of the Act.
bill_summary: The bill revises Maryland's investment policies by removing previous limitations on investments in certain commercial paper, establishing new investment thresholds through regulations, and requiring the Treasurer to notify local governments about these changes.
responsible_party: Maryland State Treasurer's Office
stakeholders: State government entities, local government units, and taxpayers in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on investment policies and thresholds is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Maryland Audiology, Hearing Aid Dispensing, Speech-Language Pathology, and Music Therapy Act - Definitions and Application
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "hearing aid dispensary" to include certain actions taken for the purpose of ordering certain hearing instruments and specifying that certain hearing instruments include prescription hearing aids; altering the definition of "practice audiology" for the purposes of certain provisions of law governing the licensure of audiologists; and providing that certain provisions of law do not apply to certain actions taken with respect to certain over-the-counter hearing aids.
bill_summary: The bill updates the definitions and scope of practice for audiology and hearing aid dispensing in Maryland, including clarifying that certain actions related to ordering and fitting hearing aids, including prescription hearing aids, are part of the practice. It also specifies that over-the-counter hearing aids are not subject to licensing requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Examiners for Audiologists, Hearing Aid Dispensers, Speech-Language Pathologists, and Music Therapists
stakeholders: Audiologists, hearing aid dispensers, individuals with hearing loss, and consumers of over-the-counter hearing aids in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill potentially reduces barriers for over-the-counter hearing aid sales, which could help small businesses by expanding market opportunities and reducing licensing burdens for certain hearing aid transactions.

Title: Kent County - Board of Education - Student Member
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Kent County Board of Education to include a student member; providing for the initial term of the student member of the county board; requiring the student member to attend the Maryland Association of Boards of Education new student board orientation and all regular meetings of the county board; prohibiting the student member's attendance at an executive session of the county board; etc.
bill_summary: The bill amends the membership structure of the Kent County Board of Education to include a nonvoting student member, elected by high school students, who will serve a one-year term starting July 1, 2024.
responsible_party: Kent County Board of Education and Kent County Public Schools
stakeholders: High school students in Kent County and the Kent County Board of Education
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it focuses on educational governance and student representation.

Title: Property Tax - Local Homeowners' Credit Supplement - Limitation on Combined Gross Income
Synopsis: Authorizing counties and municipal corporations to alter a certain limitation on the combined gross income of a homeowner for purposes of a local supplement to the homeowners' property tax credit; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2023.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes local governments in Maryland to grant property tax credits to homeowners with incomes exceeding $60,000 who have suffered hardships, and allows for the creation of local supplements to the existing homeowners' property tax credit program with flexible eligibility criteria.
responsible_party: The Department of Assessments and Taxation, local governments (counties, Baltimore City, municipal corporations)
stakeholders: Homeowners in Maryland, particularly those with incomes over $60,000 who have experienced hardships
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts homeowners and local government programs; it does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Hunting - Snares, Traps, and Other Similar Devices - Identification Requirement
Synopsis: Requiring a person who is not required to be licensed or permitted under certain provisions of law to obtain a free Department of Natural Resources identification number before using a snare, a trap, or another similar device to capture wildlife; and requiring a person who uses a snare, a trap, or another similar device to capture wildlife to ensure the person's Department identification number is stamped on the device or on a metal tag affixed to the device.
bill_summary: The bill requires individuals who are not licensed or permitted to use snares, traps, or similar devices for capturing wildlife to obtain a free identification number from the Department of Natural Resources. It also mandates that the identification number be stamped on the device or on a metal tag attached to it, with certain exceptions for private property use.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Wildlife hunters, trappers, and landowners in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates, as it primarily involves regulatory requirements for individual trappers and hunters.

Title: Elections - Polling Place Plan, Prohibited Acts, and 2024 Primary Election Date
Synopsis: Prohibiting a local board of elections from voting to change the location of a polling place without first holding a meeting to discuss the proposed change and providing an opportunity for individuals and organizations to testify; requiring each local board to submit a polling place plan to the State Board of Elections at least 6 months prior to each statewide primary election; altering the date of the 2024 statewide primary election and the primary election for municipal offices in Baltimore City to the second Tuesday in May; etc.
bill_summary: The bill introduces new regulations for polling place changes, requiring local election boards to hold public meetings and provide notices before changing polling locations. It also establishes a detailed process for submitting and approving polling place plans, and modifies election dates in 2024.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and local election boards
stakeholders: Voters in Maryland, especially those in historically disenfranchised communities, and local election officials
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Violation of Pretrial or Posttrial Condition by Incarcerated Person - Victim Contact
Synopsis: Prohibiting a certain incarcerated person from violating a condition of pretrial or posttrial release or other pretrial or posttrial condition prohibiting the person from contacting, harassing, or abusing an alleged victim or going in or near an alleged victim's residence or place of employment.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits incarcerated individuals from violating conditions of pretrial or posttrial release that restrict contact with victims, especially in cases involving minors, violent crimes, or crimes against certain protected persons. Violations are classified as misdemeanors with penalties up to 90 days in jail.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals, victims of crimes, law enforcement agencies, and the Maryland judicial system.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Mental Health - Workforce Development - Fund Established
Synopsis: Establishing the Behavioral Health Workforce Investment Fund to provide reimbursement for costs associated with educating, training, certifying, recruiting, placing, and retaining behavioral health professionals and paraprofessionals; and requiring the Maryland Health Care Commission, in coordination with certain entities, to conduct a comprehensive behavioral health workforce needs assessment on or before October 1, 2024, and submit the assessment to certain committees of the General Assembly by October 15, 2024.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Behavioral Health Workforce Investment Fund to support training, recruiting, and retaining behavioral health professionals in Maryland. It also requires a comprehensive workforce needs assessment to guide funding allocations.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health, specifically the Maryland Health Care Commission and the Department of Health.
stakeholders: Behavioral health professionals, paraprofessionals, and the populations they serve in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus on workforce development and training is likely to improve the stability and capacity of behavioral health services, which can help reduce small business failures in related health service sectors.

Title: Health Services Cost Review Commission - Hospital Rates - All-Payer Model Contract
Synopsis: Requiring that the Health Services Cost Review Commission exercise its authority to consider certain standards when determining the reasonableness of certain rates in a manner that is consistent with the all-payer model contract.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission to consider specific standards when determining the reasonableness of hospital rates, in alignment with the all-payer model contract, and grants it expanded authority to establish hospital rate levels, promote alternative payment methods, and assist with federally approved programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission
stakeholders: Hospitals, healthcare providers, and patients in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily impacts hospital rate setting and does not directly address small business failure rates.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Nonvested Accounts - Regular Interest
Synopsis: Requiring a certain rate of interest on certain member contributions in active members' nonvested accounts in the State Retirement and Pension System if the members have not withdrawn contributions from the nonvested accounts and are not eligible to receive a certain vested allowance; providing for the retroactive application of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System to pay a 4% annual interest rate on certain member contributions in nonvested accounts for active members who have not withdrawn their contributions and are not eligible for vested allowances, with retroactive application.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System who are active, nonvested members with contributions not withdrawn and not eligible for vested allowances.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to pension contributions and interest payments for retirement system members.

Title: Criminal Procedure - Medical Emergency - Immunity
Synopsis: Altering certain provisions relating to immunity from criminal arrest, charge, or prosecution for a person experiencing a medical emergency after ingesting or using alcohol or drugs.
bill_summary: The bill provides immunity from criminal arrest, charge, or prosecution for individuals who seek, provide, or assist with medical assistance during a medical emergency involving alcohol or drugs, and for those experiencing such emergencies, as long as the evidence was obtained solely due to their actions related to seeking or providing medical help.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland law enforcement agencies
stakeholders: Individuals experiencing medical emergencies related to alcohol or drug use, and those assisting them
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is not directly related to small business failure reduction, but it may indirectly support community health and safety, which can benefit local businesses.

Title: University System of Maryland - Board of Regents - Student Member Grant
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of Regents of the University System of Maryland to authorize a certain grant for the student member serving in the first year of the student's term on the Board of Regents.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the University System of Maryland to provide a grant to the student member serving on the Board of Regents during their first year of a two-year term, and a tuition waiver during their second year, with specific limits and conditions.
responsible_party: University System of Maryland Board of Regents
stakeholders: Student members serving on the University System of Maryland Board of Regents
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Procurement Improvement Council - Membership and Duties
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the Procurement Improvement Council to include the Comptroller and the Attorney General; authorizing certain members to send a designee to attend certain meetings under certain circumstances; and clarifying the duties of the Council to include discussion of strategies to increase the participation of small, minority-owned, and women-owned businesses in procurement contracts.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the membership and duties of the Maryland Procurement Improvement Council, including clarifying designee provisions for certain members and emphasizing strategies to increase participation of small, minority-owned, and women-owned businesses in procurement.
responsible_party: The Procurement Improvement Council, led by the Chief Procurement Officer, and the Maryland State government agencies involved in procurement.
stakeholders: State procurement agencies, small businesses, minority-owned businesses, women-owned businesses, and other organizations involved in Maryland's procurement process.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to increase participation of small, minority-owned, and women-owned businesses in procurement, which could help reduce small business failures by providing more opportunities.

Title: Prince George's County - Office of the Sheriff - Deputy Sheriffs and Labor Organizations PG 308-23
Synopsis: Increasing from four to five the number of full-time assistant sheriffs provided to the Sheriff of Prince George's County; and providing that the Fraternal Order of Police will negotiate on behalf of deputy sheriffs in benefit matters not related to salary.
bill_summary: The bill increases the number of full-time assistant sheriffs in Prince George's County, clarifies the responsibilities and investigative authority of the Sheriff and deputy sheriffs, and modifies the negotiation process for benefits and duties of law enforcement personnel.
responsible_party: Prince George's County Office of the Sheriff
stakeholders: Law enforcement personnel, residents of Prince George's County, and small businesses involved in county events and security services.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions on law enforcement duties and negotiations are unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates.

Title: Prince George's County - Speed Monitoring Systems - Maryland Route 210 (Indian Head Highway) PG 304-23
Synopsis: Increasing the maximum number of speed monitoring systems that may be placed and used on Maryland Route 210 (Indian Head Highway) in Prince George's County from three to six; requiring the State Highway Administration in conjunction with a certain entity to report annually its recommendations for solutions to address accidents, injuries, and fatalities on the highway; extending the termination date for a provision of law granting the authority to place speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 210 in Prince George's County; etc.
bill_summary: The bill increases the number of speed monitoring systems allowed on Maryland Route 210 in Prince George's County, extends the authority to place these systems, and modifies reporting and examination requirements related to traffic safety on the highway.
responsible_party: Maryland State Highway Administration in conjunction with the Prince George’s County Department of Public Works and Transportation.
stakeholders: Motorists and residents in Prince George's County, especially those near Maryland Route 210, and local government agencies involved in traffic safety and enforcement.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure; it focuses on traffic safety and monitoring systems.

Title: Prince George's County - Alcoholic Beverages - Licensing PG 305-23
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County, notwithstanding a certain prohibition on the transfer of a license with an off-sale privilege, to approve the transfer of a Class A beer, wine, and liquor license to a premises located in a certain alcoholic beverages district under certain circumstances; authorizing the Board to issue a Class B-DD beer, wine, and liquor license with an off-sale privilege to certain restaurants in certain areas; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County to transfer certain alcoholic beverage licenses and issue new licenses, including Class B–DD licenses with off-sale privileges, in specific areas within the county, particularly on Central Avenue and other designated development districts.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Prince George's County
stakeholders: Restaurants and alcohol license holders in Prince George's County, especially those in designated development districts and on Central Avenue.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to facilitate the issuance and transfer of alcohol licenses, potentially reducing barriers for restaurants and small businesses to operate and expand, thereby lowering the risk of business failure.

Title: Prince George's County Public Schools - Alterations to Title of Chief Executive Officer and Establishment of Office of Integrity and Compliance PG 501-23
Synopsis: Changing the title of the Chief Executive Officer of the Prince George's County public school system to the County Superintendent of the Prince George's County public school system; establishing the Office of Integrity and Compliance in the Prince George's County public school system to evaluate, examine, investigate, report on, and make recommendations on certain issues related to the Prince George's County public school system; requiring the County Council of Prince George's County to appoint an Integrity and Compliance officer; etc.
bill_summary: The bill changes the title of the Chief Executive Officer of Prince George's County Public Schools to the County Superintendent, establishes the Office of Integrity and Compliance to oversee accountability, investigate issues, and report on the school system's effectiveness, and sets procedures for appointing and managing the new office and the County Superintendent.
responsible_party: Prince George’s County Council and the Office of the County Superintendent of Prince George’s County Public Schools
stakeholders: Students, staff, vendors, and residents of Prince George’s County involved with or affected by the public school system and its accountability measures.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill promotes increased participation of local small and minority businesses in school procurement through a new certification and participation program, which could help these businesses succeed and reduce failures.

Title: Prince George's County - Alcoholic Beverages - Class B-Stadium (Baseball Stadium) Beer, Wine, and Liquor License PG 306-23
Synopsis: Altering the alcoholic beverages that may be sold under a certain stadium license in Prince George's County; authorizing the holder of a Class B-Stadium (baseball stadium) beer, wine, and liquor license to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption; altering a provision of law providing that the profit from the sale of certain alcoholic beverages under the license may accrue to the use of the Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission or the concessionaire; etc.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the alcoholic beverage licensing laws in Prince George's County, allowing the holder of a Class B–Stadium license for baseball stadiums to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption, and clarifies the allocation of profits from these sales.
responsible_party: Prince George's County Alcoholic Beverages Board and the Maryland–National Capital Park and Planning Commission
stakeholders: Businesses operating stadiums in Prince George's County, stadium concessionaires, and consumers attending events at these stadiums.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's provisions are unlikely to have a direct impact on reducing small business failure rates, as it primarily clarifies licensing and profit allocation for stadium beverage sales.

Title: Child Custody - Relocation of Child - Expedited Hearing (Assurance of Child's Safety Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a court to schedule a hearing on a certain petition regarding the proposed relocation of a child who is the subject of a custody or visitation order on an expedited basis under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill requires courts to hold expedited hearings in child custody or visitation cases when a parent files a petition to relocate a child, especially if the move is over 40 miles away or significantly interferes with parenting time. It also clarifies that a child's time with a parent who relocates in violation of notice provisions cannot be used as an advantage in custody decisions.
responsible_party: Maryland family courts and judges responsible for child custody and visitation cases.
stakeholders: Children and their parents involved in custody and visitation disputes, particularly those considering relocation.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it focuses on child custody and visitation procedures.

Title: Prince George's County - Payment in Lieu of Taxes Agreements - Low-Income Housing PG 403-23
Synopsis: Authorizing the governing body of Prince George's County to enter into a payment in lieu of taxes agreement with an owner of real property that is used for low-income housing that is financed through the county's Right of First Refusal program or acquired, constructed, or rehabilitated for the purposes of operating the low-income housing.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Prince George's County to enter into agreements with owners of low-income housing for payment in lieu of taxes, especially for properties financed or acquired under specific programs, to support affordable housing.
responsible_party: Prince George's County government
stakeholders: Owners of low-income housing properties and low-income residents in Prince George's County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily supports affordable housing initiatives and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Nonpublic Education - Placements of Children With Disabilities - Teacher Salaries (Teacher Pay Parity Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the State Department of Education to adopt regulations to ensure that children with disabilities who need special education and related services that cannot be provided in a public county, regional, or State program be placed in an appropriate nonpublic educational program that offers these services; requiring the State and certain counties to pay for costs of salaries for teachers at certain nonpublic schools in a certain amount and proportion; etc.
bill_summary: The bill, known as the Teacher Pay Parity Act, aims to rename nonpublic educational programs to special education placements and mandates that the State and counties fund teacher salaries at these placements to ensure parity with public school salaries. It establishes funding and regulatory guidelines to support teachers at nonpublic special education schools, including phased salary parity over three years.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Children with disabilities, teachers at nonpublic special education schools, and their families
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill primarily focuses on public and nonpublic educational placements and teacher salaries, with no direct provisions targeting small business failure reduction.

Title: State Board of Physicians - Inactive and Emeritus Status
Synopsis: Authorizing the Board to place a licensee on emeritus status under certain circumstances; requiring the Board, under certain circumstances, to reinstate the license of an individual who is on inactive or emeritus status; exempting licensees who are on inactive status or emeritus status from continuing medical education requirements; repealing the requirement that the Board issue a license to an individual who is on inactive status under certain circumstances; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland State Board of Physicians to place physicians on emeritus status, establish criteria for such status, and clarify rules regarding inactive status. It also sets regulations for reinstating licenses, practicing medicine, and using medical titles for licensees on inactive or emeritus status.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Physicians
stakeholders: Physicians licensed in Maryland, especially those on inactive or emeritus status, and the general public seeking medical services in Maryland.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's impact on small business failure rates is minimal, as it primarily deals with licensing and status regulations for physicians rather than business operations.

Title: Health Occupations - Licenses, Certificates, and Registrations - Lawful Presence and Identification Numbers
Synopsis: Prohibiting a health occupations board from requiring that an applicant provide proof that the applicant is lawfully present in the United States or have a Social Security number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number as a condition for licensure, certification, or registration; requiring each health occupations board to require each applicant for a license to disclose the Social Security number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number of the applicant or, as permitted by federal law, provide alternative documentation; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits health occupations boards in Maryland from denying licenses, certifications, or registrations to immigrants if they meet certain requirements, such as providing proof of lawful presence in the U.S. or having a Social Security or Taxpayer Identification Number. It also mandates disclosure of Social Security or TIN numbers during application and updates reporting requirements for licensing authorities.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and other health occupations licensing boards
stakeholders: Immigrants seeking health licenses, certifications, or registrations in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill streamlines licensing processes for immigrants, potentially reducing barriers and delays that could lead to small business failures in the health sector.

Title: Video Lottery Terminal Proceeds - Purse Dedication Account - Ocean Downs Race Course Operating Loss Assistance
Synopsis: Altering the authority of the Ocean Downs Race Course to use certain Purse Dedication Account funds generated from video lottery terminal proceeds for operating loss assistance to support a certain minimum number of live racing days at the racecourse.
bill_summary: The bill allows Ocean Downs Race Course to use funds from the Purse Dedication Account, generated from video lottery terminal proceeds, to help cover operating losses and support a minimum of 40 live racing days annually.
responsible_party: Maryland State Racing Commission and the Ocean Downs Race Course
stakeholders: Horse racing industry, local communities around Ocean Downs, and bettors who participate in live racing events.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill provides financial assistance to Ocean Downs Race Course to cover operating losses, which can help prevent business failure and sustain the racing operations.

Title: State Board of Pharmacy - Accessible Prescription Labels, Bag Tags, and Medical Guides for Blind, Visually Impaired, and Print Disabled Individuals - Regulations
Synopsis: Requiring the State Board of Pharmacy to adopt regulations necessary to ensure that individuals who are blind, visually impaired, or otherwise print disabled have appropriate access to prescription labels, bag tags, and medical guides; requiring the Board to give visually impaired individuals an opportunity to comment on the regulations; and requiring the Maryland Department of Health to report by December 1, 2023, to the General Assembly on the implementation process for providing accessible labels for visually impaired persons.
bill_summary: The bill requires pharmacies to inform customers about the availability of accessible prescription labels for blind, visually impaired, or print-disabled individuals and to provide these labels upon request. It establishes standards for accessible labels and prescription readers, and mandates the Maryland State Board of Pharmacy to adopt regulations ensuring access to prescription information in accessible formats.
responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Pharmacy
stakeholders: Blind, visually impaired, and print-disabled individuals who use prescription medications
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill could potentially reduce small business failure by improving accessibility and customer service, but its direct impact on failure rates is limited and primarily related to compliance with new regulations.

Title: Public School Construction - Programs, Approvals, and Administration - Alterations
Synopsis: Repealing the School Safety Grant Program and the Aging Schools Program as of June 30, 2026; altering provisions relating to school construction approvals by the State Superintendent of Schools; altering provisions related to a public-private partnership agreement in Prince George's County; establishing that the Interagency Commission on School Construction is an independent unit of State government; repealing the requirement for the Board of Public Works to approve grants awarded under a certain capital grant program; etc.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the School Safety Grant Program and the Aging Schools Program, modifies school construction approval processes, establishes the Interagency Commission on School Construction as an independent entity, and updates funding and program administration related to public school construction, including public-private partnerships in Prince George's County.
responsible_party: The Interagency Commission on School Construction and the Maryland Stadium Authority are responsible for implementing the programs.
stakeholders: Public school students, school staff, local school districts, and residents of Prince George's County.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill introduces a public-private partnership program and funding mechanisms that could potentially reduce small business failures by fostering collaboration and providing new opportunities in school construction projects.

Title: State Board of Architects - Sunset Extension
Synopsis: Continuing the State Board of Architects in accordance with the provisions of the Maryland Program Evaluation Act (sunset law) by extending to July 1, 2028, the termination provisions relating to certain statutory and regulatory authority of the Board.
bill_summary: The bill extends the sunset date for the State Board of Architects in Maryland from 2023 to 2028, ensuring the continued existence and authority of the Board.
responsible_party: State Board of Architects in the Department of Maryland
stakeholders: Architects and architecture firms in Maryland, and the general public who rely on licensed architects
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's extension of the Board's authority helps maintain regulatory oversight, which can support the stability of architecture-related small businesses.

Title: Natural Resources - Recreational Crabbing Gear - Individuals Under the Age of 16 Years
Synopsis: Authorizing an individual under the age of 16 years to use a collapsible trap, net ring, handline, or dip net when catching or attempting to catch crabs in the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries without a recreational crabbing license.
bill_summary: The bill exempts individuals under 16 years old from needing a recreational crabbing license to catch crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries. It also allows these minors to use specific gear such as collapsible traps, net rings, handlines, or dip nets.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Individuals under 16 years old who enjoy recreational crabbing in Maryland waters
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill is unlikely to have a direct impact on small business failure rates, as it primarily concerns minors and recreational activities.

Title: Worcester County - Natural Resources - Hunting
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of Natural Resources to allow a person in Worcester County to hunt game birds and game mammals on a Sunday, subject to certain time restrictions, during the open season for that game bird or game mammal; authorizing the Department to allow a person in Worcester County to hunt on public land designated for hunting on Sundays, subject to certain time restrictions; and altering the safety zone from 150 to 50 yards from certain buildings occupied by human beings within which archery hunting may not take place.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to allow hunting on Sundays in Worcester County during specific seasons and on designated public lands, with certain time restrictions and safety zone modifications. It also clarifies hunting regulations and safety zones for various counties.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Hunters and residents in Worcester County and other counties with hunting regulations, including youth hunters and organized hunting groups.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on hunting regulations and safety zones; it does not directly address small business failure or economic development.

Title: Environment - Fire-Fighting Training - Oriented Strand Board - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting the setting on fire or burning of oriented strand board for certain fire-fighting training; and establishing an administrative penalty not exceeding $500 for a first violation of the Act and a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000 for a second or subsequent violation of the Act.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits setting fire to or burning oriented strand board (OSB) for fire-fighting training purposes, with penalties for violations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Fire departments and training organizations in Maryland, and communities served by these fire-fighting agencies.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Economic Development – Regional Institution Strategic Enterprise Zone Program – Alterations and Financing
Synopsis: Altering the period of time that an area may be designated as a Regional Institution Strategic Enterprise (RISE) zone from 5 to 10 years; increasing the number of RISE zones that the Secretary of Commerce may approve in Baltimore City to not more than four; extending the termination date of the RISE Program to January 1, 2030; and authorizing a political subdivision to pledge certain revenues to secure the payment of obligations to the Maryland Economic Development Corporation for infrastructure improvements located in a RISE zone.
bill_summary: The bill extends the designation period for RISE zones from 5 to 10 years, allows renewal for an additional 5 years, increases the number of RISE zones that can be approved in Baltimore City, and extends the program's termination date to 2030. It also authorizes political subdivisions to pledge revenues to secure infrastructure financing and mandates a study on the program's effectiveness.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
stakeholders: Qualified institutions, counties, municipal corporations, economic development agencies, and communities within RISE zones
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to support economic development and infrastructure improvements in designated zones, which can help small businesses by improving local conditions and access to resources, potentially reducing failure rates.

Title: Public Senior Higher Education Institutions - Reproductive Health Services Plans - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring, on or before August 1, 2024, certain public senior higher education institutions, in consultation with students, to develop and implement a reproductive health services plan to provide at the institution or to refer students to a comprehensive range of reproductive health services; requiring the University of Baltimore, in lieu of developing and implementing a reproductive health services plan, to provide students with access to over-the-counter contraception through certain on-campus means; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires certain public senior higher education institutions in Maryland to develop and implement reproductive health services plans, including access to contraception, STI prevention, and abortion services, in consultation with students. It also allows the University of Baltimore to provide students with over-the-counter contraception through on-campus vending machines or retail establishments.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and public senior higher education institutions
stakeholders: Students at public senior higher education institutions in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill may indirectly support student health and well-being, but it does not directly target small business failure rates.

Title: Department of Veterans Affairs - Burial in State Veterans' Cemeteries - Spouses and Dependents
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Veterans Affairs to bury the eligible spouse or dependent of a veteran in a State veterans' cemetery without charge.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs to provide burial plots at no charge for spouses and dependents of veterans in state veterans' cemeteries, including covering the costs for opening and closing the plots.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
stakeholders: Spouses and dependents of veterans in Maryland, and veterans themselves
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly impact small business failure rates, as it pertains to veterans' burial services.

Title: Grossly Negligent or Drunk or Drugged Operation of Vehicle or Vessel - Prior Convictions
Synopsis: Establishing that certain previous convictions for drunk or drugged operation of a vehicle or vessel and grossly negligent manslaughter by vehicle or vessel under certain provisions of law constitute prior convictions for the purpose of determining certain enhanced subsequent offender penalties.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland law to recognize prior convictions for drunk or drugged operation of vehicles and vessels, as well as grossly negligent manslaughter by vehicle or vessel, for the purpose of enhancing penalties for repeat offenders.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources and Maryland Department of Transportation
stakeholders: Individuals convicted of operating vehicles or vessels under the influence of alcohol or drugs in Maryland
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates; it focuses on criminal penalties for operating under influence.

Title: Task Force to Study Nonpublic Student Bus Transportation
Synopsis: Establishing the Task Force to Study Nonpublic Student Bus Transportation to collect information from each local board of education on nonpublic school student busing programs other than for the transportation of students in special education; and requiring the Task Force to report by December 15, 2023, to certain committees of the General Assembly any recommendations as to how the State may support a reduction in the use of passenger vehicles for nonpublic school students and policies for certain busing programs.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Task Force to study nonpublic student bus transportation and consider implementing a tax credit for parents or guardians of students who pay transportation expenses for nonpublic schools. It also creates a refundable state income tax credit of up to $1,500 per student for qualified bus transportation expenses.
responsible_party: The Maryland State Department of Education, in collaboration with the Maryland Department of Transportation and other relevant agencies, is responsible for implementing the programs and recommendations.
stakeholders: Parents or guardians of students attending nonpublic elementary or secondary schools in Maryland, nonpublic schools, school bus drivers, and local education agencies.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill does not directly address small business failure rates, but by studying transportation options and potential support, it may influence transportation service providers and related small businesses indirectly.

Title: Anne Arundel County - School Vehicles - Duration of Operation
Synopsis: Altering the number of years that a school vehicle may be operated in Anne Arundel County from 12 years to 15 years.
bill_summary: The bill amends the regulations for operating school vehicles in Anne Arundel County, allowing them to be operated for up to 15 years instead of 12, provided they meet certain safety and maintenance standards.
responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Department of Education and the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration
stakeholders: School children, school transportation staff, and residents of Anne Arundel County
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill's focus is on vehicle operation standards and does not directly impact small business failure rates.

Title: Early Childhood Development - Child Care Scholarship Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Prohibiting the State Department of Education from increasing the copayment levels, reducing the reimbursement rates, reducing the income eligibility requirements, or implementing an enrollment freeze for the Child Care Scholarship Program in effect as of January 1, 2023, unless certain conditions are met.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the funding, eligibility, and reimbursement rate calculations for Maryland's Child Care Scholarship Program, including restrictions on program freezes and adjustments to copayment and income eligibility requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
stakeholders: Child care providers, families eligible for child care assistance, and low-income families seeking child care support.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill aims to stabilize funding and reimbursement rates for child care providers, which can help reduce the risk of small business failure in the child care sector.

Title: Rural Health Collaborative Pilot Repeal and Mid Shore Health Improvement Coalition Funding
Synopsis: Repealing the provisions of law establishing and governing the Rural Health Collaborative Pilot; and requiring the Governor to provide an appropriation in the State budget for fiscal year 2024 and each fiscal year thereafter to fund the operations of the Mid Shore Health Improvement Coalition.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the Rural Health Collaborative Pilot in the mid-shore region and establishes ongoing funding for the Mid Shore Health Improvement Coalition to improve healthcare access and services in that region.
responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health, specifically the Mid Shore Health Improvement Coalition, which is funded and overseen by the state government.
stakeholders: Residents and healthcare providers in the mid-shore region of Maryland, including counties such as Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne’s, and Talbot.
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: The bill focuses on healthcare system improvements and does not directly address small business failure rates, so its impact on small business failure is minimal.

Title: Board of Public Works Public Comment Act
Synopsis: Requiring the Board of Public Works, for meetings held on or after October 1, 2024, to allow members of the public to submit certain public comments electronically except under certain circumstances; requiring public comments to be included in certain meeting materials and posted and retained online; and requiring an additional staff position at the Board to carry out requirements of the Act.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Board of Public Works to allow the public to submit comments electronically for meetings starting from October 1, 2024. These comments must be included in meeting materials, posted online at least 24 hours before the meeting, and retained online. The bill also mandates the hiring of an additional staff member to manage these requirements.
responsible_party: Maryland Board of Public Works and its staff
stakeholders: Members of the public interested in Maryland public meetings and decision-making processes
decrease_small_business_failure_summary: This bill does not directly impact small businesses or their failure rates.

Title: Department of Human Services - Electronic Benefits Transfer Cards - Theft of Benefits (Prevent Electronic Benefits Theft Act of 2023)
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Human Services to restore to a beneficiary any benefits lost due to theft; authorizing certain households to request a hearing within 90 days after a certain determination; requiring the State to give preference to certain vendors in the procurement process for electronic benefits distribution or administration; authorizing the Department to restore certain benefits; requiring the Department to take certain actions to reduce the vulnerability of Electronic Benefits Transfer cards to theft; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Human Services to reimburse beneficiaries for benefits lost due to theft or fraudulent use of Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) cards. It establishes procedures for reporting, investigating, and restoring stolen benefits, and mandates improvements in the security of EBT cards, including the use of microchips and enhanced fraud detection measures.
